P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported - [NA]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "A total of 319 articles were identified in the initial search." - [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Among the different techniques presented in 19 papers collected, we categorized reconstructive procedures into two groups: microsurgical and non-microsurgical techniques." - [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported - [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Among the microsurgical techniques, procedures such as the osteocutaneous fibular flap (n = 18), the myocutaneous latissimus dorsi flap (n = 24), and the radial forearm free flap (n = 293) were reported." - [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no additional analyses) - [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Taking recent literature into account, it seems rational that neophalloplasty be regarded as the preferred strategy for boys born with aphallia." - [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: Not reported - [No]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "As a personal input, based on this review and considering our personal experience, we still believe that flap techniques should be the first choice when treating a child with penile agenesis." - [Yes]
P27. Funding: Not reported - [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Open Versus Laparoscopic Pyloromyotomy for Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Focusing on Major Complications"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The aim of this study was to compare the results of both surgical strategies by means of a systematic review and meta-analysis of the available literature."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "There is an ongoing debate about whether laparoscopic pyloromyotomy (LP) or open pyloromyotomy (OP) is the best option for treating hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS)."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The aim of this study was to compare the results of LP and OP by means of a systematic review of the available randomized trials while focusing on major complications."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No information provided.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Studies were included in the review if they were RCTs that compared the results of LP and OP in children with HPS with admission time after pyloromyotomy and postoperative complication rate as outcomes."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A systematic search for RCTs that compared open and LP was conducted. Retrieval of studies was performed through a systematic search of the databases PubMed, Ovid and Cochrane."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: No information provided.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Potentially eligible studies were reviewed independently by two authors for inclusion and exclusion criteria."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Data on setting, methodological quality, population, and type of surgery were extracted by two authors independently, as well as data on primary and secondary outcome measures."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: No information provided.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No information provided.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Results for comparisons of dichotomous outcomes (e.g., major postoperative complications) are expressed as risk differences with 95% confidence intervals."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: [NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: [NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: [NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "The initial search yielded 361 potentially relevant articles, of which 346 articles were excluded because of failure to meet the inclusion criteria."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Four RCTs with a total of 502 patients (OP 255, LP 247) fulfilled the inclusion criteria and were analyzed in this review."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No information provided.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "All studies included in this review reported major complications, with a total of 12 (4.9%) major complications in children who underwent LP and 5 (2.0%) in the OP group."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: [NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: [NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: [NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "In our systematic review of high-level evidence, LP was found to be superior to OP with respect to a shorter time to full feed but not regarding (major) postoperative complications or length of hospital stay."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "There are still contradictory results in the literature with regard to the benefits and disadvantages of LP compared to the open procedure to treat infants with HPS."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "In this systematic review we summarized all RCTs available in the pediatric surgical literature, focusing mainly on major complications that need surgical reintervention in patients with HPS. However, our results show no clear benefit of the laparoscopic procedure over the open operation."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: "Dr. M. W. N. Oomen, Dr. L. T. Hoekstra, Dr. R. Bakx, Dr. D. T. Ubbink, and Prof. Dr. H. A. Heij have no conflicts of interest or financial ties to disclose."
[Yes]

P1. Title: "The management of newborns with esophageal atresia and right aortic arch: A systematic review or still unsolved problem"
[Yes] The report is identified as a systematic review.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "This study provides a systematic review of epidemiology, diagnosis, management and short-term results of children with EA and RAA."
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The management of newborns with esophageal atresia (EA) and right aortic arch (RAA) is still an unsolved problem."
[Yes] The rationale for the review is described.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "This study provides a systematic review of the literature, focusing on epidemiology, diagnostic assessment and management of children with EA and RAA, comparing the morbidity and mortality rates of different surgical strategies."
[Yes] The objectives of the review are explicitly stated.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not applicable (no mention of a review protocol or registration information).
[NA]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Inclusion criteria were English language articles reporting original data on epidemiology, diagnosis and treatment of newborns with EA."
[Yes] The study characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.

P7. Methods / Information sources: "The PubMed database was searched for studies of children with EA and RAA published from January 1990 to December 2014."
[Yes] The information sources are described.

P8. Methods / Search: "The PubMed database was searched for studies of children with EA and RAA published from January 1990 to December 2014."
[Yes] The full electronic search strategy is presented.

P9. Methods / Study selection: "The study selection process is shown in Fig. 1."
[Yes] The process for selecting studies is described and a flow diagram is provided.

[Yes] The method of data extraction is described.

[Yes] The data items for which data were sought are listed and defined.

[NA]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not applicable (no mention of summary measures).
[NA]

[NA]

[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no mention of additional analyses).
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "Eight eligible articles met the inclusion criteria in the end."
[Yes] The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are given.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Eight eligible articles met the inclusion criteria in the end."
[Yes] The characteristics for which data were extracted are mentioned.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not applicable (no mention of risk of bias assessment within studies).
[NA]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "RAA was encountered in 3.6% of infants."
[Yes] The results of individual studies are presented.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no mention of data synthesis).
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no mention of risk of bias assessment across studies).
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no mention of additional analyses).
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "The surgical treatment of an infant with EA and RAA is technically challenging and most studies reported some operative difficulties."
[Yes] The main findings are summarized, including the strength of evidence for each main outcome.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "This systematic review had some inherent limitations, including a relatively small number of patients and retrospective case series without a control arm."
[Yes] The limitations of the review are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "A multicenter prospective study comparing RT and LT in infants with EA and RAA is strongly required."
[Yes] The general interpretation of the results is provided, along with implications for future research.

P27. Funding: Not mentioned.

P1. Title: "[No]" - The title does not identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "[Yes]" - The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "[Yes]" - The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "[Yes]" - The introduction provides an explicit statement of the questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design.
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: "[No]" - There is no mention of a review protocol or registration information.

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Meta-analysis of complication rates of the tubularized incised plate (TIP) repair"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "To determine overall complication rates of the tubularized incised plate (TIP) repair and assess the effects of technical modifications, length of follow-up and geographical location of reported results."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "There is a wide discrepancy between published complication rates for different repair types and a poor evidence base for the current management of hypospadias."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "Assessing the appropriateness of its application to all degrees of hypospadias; Evaluating the long-term results by analyzing the pooled complication rates to accurately determine representative complication rates for this technique; Reviewing the effects of technical modifications, length of follow-up and geographical location of these complications."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Paediatric populations solely; TIP technique used; Complications given for at least one of those under consideration; Population previously unreported; Article in English; No foreskin reconstruction; Results separated by meatal location and primary or secondary repair."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "Medline and Pubmed were searched in order to identify articles published between 1994 and 2012."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "The search terms ‘tubularized incised plate urethroplasty/Snodgrass repair/technique ± outcomes/complications ± follow-up/long term follow-up’ were used."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "The following data were extracted independently from each article by two reviewers: study size; degree of hypospadias; primary or secondary repair; repair type; modification (if used); mean length of follow-up; study duration; geographical location; and rates of meatal stenosis, fistula, urethral stricture and unplanned re-operation to treat complications."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
[NA]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Proportions were expressed on the logit scale for analysis, and 0.5 was added to the numerator and denominators of outcomes with no events to prevent infinities."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not reported.
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not reported.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "Of the 189 articles that were identified, 49 studies (4675 patients) were included in the analysis."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: Not reported.
[NA]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
[NA]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Fistula and re-operation rates were significantly higher in secondary repairs compared to primary proximal and primary distal; Technical modifications reduced fistula rates from 10.3% to 3.3% and re-operation rates from 13.6% to 2.8%; The rate of meatal stenosis was highest in the secondary repairs, with follow-up >1 year; Comparison of geographical location showed that complication rates for all but one variable were significantly lower in North America when compared to Europe and the rest of the world."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not reported.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not reported.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "The present meta-analysis has shown that the lowest complication rates for the TIP repair are when it is applied to primary distal hypospadias; Lower complication rates than those reported in this TIP review have been documented in some studies using a staged repair for correction of primary proximal or secondary hypospadias, implying that a staged approach may be superior to the TIP repair in these settings."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "Documentation of follow-up duration was limited, making assessment of the impact of length of follow-up difficult; Geographical location had a noticeable effect on outcome, with all but one complication being lower in the North American than the other groups; Additional long-term follow-up papers are required to further evaluate this popular hypospadias technique that has now been in use for 18 years."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "The TIP repair has evolved to incorporate modifications that have significantly lowered complications; Higher complication rates are seen with secondary and proximal repairs; Limited, published long-term data impair a true assessment of outcome."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: "None of the authors have any conflicts of interest or funding to declare."
[Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Ureteroscopy: The standard of care in the management of upper tract urolithiasis in children"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The purpose of this review article is to demonstrate that ureteroscopic lithotripsy is now to be considered the standard of care in the management of upper tract urolithiasis in the pediatric patient, replacing shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) as the first line of therapy."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The purpose of this study is to determine whether the safety and efficacy of URS now warrant it being considered the standard of care and the first line of therapy in the management of pediatric urolithiasis."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The purpose of this review article is to demonstrate that ureteroscopic lithotripsy is now to be considered the standard of care in the management of upper tract urolithiasis in the pediatric patient, replacing shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) as the first line of therapy."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not applicable (no mention of a protocol or registration)
[NA]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Not applicable (no mention of study or report characteristics used as eligibility criteria)
[NA]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A systematic review of articles written about ureteroscopy (URS) in the contemporary urological literature (1990-2009) on PubMed was undertaken."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)."
[No]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Demographic information, including patient age, gender, presenting symptoms, number of URS procedures performed and stone-free rate, were abstracted from the papers reviewed."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted)
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted)
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted)
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: Not reported
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Over the past 20 years, the results of 832 pediatric patients (mean age, 9.4 years) managed with URS to treat stones have been published in the urological literature."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "In over 832 URS cases, there was a 5.9% complication rate and a stone-free rate of 93.4%."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted)
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted)
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted)
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "URS is safe and efficacious in the management of pediatric urolithiasis."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The rationale for stent placement has traditionally been a potential decrease in stricture formation and post-operative pain; however, it is a well-known fact that ureteral stents can actually be the cause of significant pain."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "URS should be considered an essential part of the armamentarium of any urologist involved in the care of children and is now considered the standard of care for the management of pediatric urolithiasis."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: Not reported
[No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "The role of preformed silos in the management of infants with gastroschisis: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis of the literature comparing use of a PFS with alternate treatment strategies."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The optimum surgical treatment of infants born with gastroschisis remains unclear."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "We aimed to evaluate current evidence comparing the use of a PFS with alternate treatment strategies in infants with gastroschisis."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Studies were selected for inclusion in the review if they reported comparative outcomes between infants treated with a PFS and infants treated with an alternate treatment strategy."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "We searched Medline, Embase and the Cochrane controlled trials register from inception to July 2014 using the terms 'gastroschisis', 'gastroschisis and silo', 'preformed silo' and 'silastic silo'."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Studies were selected for inclusion in the review if they reported comparative outcomes between infants treated with a PFS and infants treated with an alternate treatment strategy."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Not reported.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items: "All outcomes were selected a priori. The primary outcome measure was time on a ventilator. Secondary outcomes were number of infants never ventilated, time on parenteral nutrition (PN), time to achieve full enteral feeds, length of hospital stay, incidence of necrotising enterocolitis, number of unplanned re-operations, infectious complications, mortality and occurrence of ventral hernia following repair."
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Mean difference (MD) between continuous variables and 95 % confidence intervals were calculated. Risk difference and 95 % CI were determined for dichotomous data."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable.
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "One-thousand five-hundred and sixty-seven articles were identified using the specified search criteria and their abstracts reviewed. Following application against our inclusion criteria, 1440 were excluded on the basis of their abstract alone and the full text of 127 publications was scrutinised. One hundred and seven of these were subsequently excluded as they did not report a comparative group, did not use a PFS, or did not report outcomes from a group all treated with a PFS. The remaining 18 publications were included in this systematic review."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Of these 18, four met the criteria for inclusion in the subgroup analysis."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "The primary outcome of number of days of ventilation was reported in 8 studies (641 patients). In the overall analysis there was no statistically significant difference in number of days of ventilation between infants treated with a PFS and alternate techniques."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "This review demonstrates that use of a PFS results in largely equivalent outcomes compared to alternate treatment approaches for infants with gastroschisis."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The quality of evidence comparing PFS with alternate treatment strategies for gastroschisis is poor."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Further investigation is required to identify not only the optimal treatment pathway for infants with gastroschisis which will likely include a case by case decision algorithm, but also the tools by which to measure success."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: Not reported.
[No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Single-Incision Pediatric Endosurgery: A Systematic Review" [Yes]
P2. Abstract: "Several publications exist, but no previous systematic review has been made to evaluate the real benefits of this approach in terms of feasibility and clinical outcomes." [Yes]
P3. Introduction: "In the search for less invasive procedures, ever since the development of laparoscopic surgery and with the limitations and equipment dependence of Natural Orifice Translumenal endoscopic surgery (NOTES®; American Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy [Oak Brook, IL] and Society of American Gastrointestinal and Endoscopic Surgeons [Los Angeles, CA]), this new approach through the umbilicus, a natural embrionary orifice,1 was first reported in 1992 by Pelosi and Pelosi.2 Quickly, the literature showed that SIES was a feasible and excellent cosmetic procedure pending the demonstration of its clinical and economic benefits with objective evidence." [Yes]
P4. Objectives: "The objective of this review is to show the initial published experience about SIPES to evaluate its real benefits in terms of feasibility and clinical outcomes." [Yes]
P5. Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]
P6. Eligibility criteria: "We performed a systematic review of the literature to find out the current state of SIPES procedures, including age, technical aspects, and operative outcomes." [Yes]
P7. Information sources: "We performed an electronic search in PubMed up to March 2012 with the terms 'single AND incision OR site OR port OR trocar AND children' including related articles and obtained 197 articles." [Yes]
P8. Search: Not reported [No]
P9. Study selection: "After applying our eligibility criteria, we selected 78 articles to be included in this systematic review." [Yes]
P10. Data collection process: "Data extracted from these articles were further analyzed for (1) technical aspects (port and instrumentation type) and (2) operative outcomes (operative time, conversion rate, length of stay, pain assessment, and complications)." [Yes]
P11. Data items: Not reported [No]
P12. Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported [No]
P13. Summary measures: Not reported [No]
P14. Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P15. Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P16. Additional analyses: Not reported [No]
P17. Study selection: "Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram." [Yes]
P18. Study characteristics: "For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations." [Yes]
P19. Risk of bias within studies: "Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment." [Yes]
P20. Results of individual studies: "For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot." [Yes]
P21. Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P22. Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P23. Additional analysis: Not reported [No]
P24. Summary of evidence: "Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers)." [Yes]
P25. Limitations: "Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias)." [Yes]
P26. Conclusions: "Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research." [Yes]
P27. Funding: Not reported [No]

P1. Title: "Laparoscopic versus open surgery for suspected appendicitis" [Yes]
- The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review comparing laparoscopic and open surgery for suspected appendicitis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "To compare the diagnostic and therapeutic effects of laparoscopic and conventional 'open' surgery." [Yes]
- The abstract provides a structured summary that includes the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Laparoscopic surgery for acute appendicitis has been proposed to have advantages over conventional surgery." [Yes]
- The introduction provides the rationale for the review by stating that laparoscopic surgery has been proposed to have advantages over conventional surgery for acute appendicitis.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To compare the diagnostic and therapeutic effects of laparoscopic and conventional 'open' surgery." [Yes]
- The objectives are explicitly stated as comparing the diagnostic and therapeutic effects of laparoscopic and conventional surgery.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Laparoscopic Duhamel Procedure for Hirschsprung's Disease: Systematic Review and Meta-analysis"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "This study compared long-term outcomes for open Duhamel (OD) and laparoscopic Duhamel (LD) procedures for HD, to identify any added advantage of the laparoscopic technique."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Our study is the first systematic review and meta-analysis comparing the two approaches."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "This study compared long-term outcomes for open Duhamel (OD) and laparoscopic Duhamel (LD) procedures for HD, to identify any added advantage of the laparoscopic technique."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "All studies between January 1994 and December 2014 were included in the search, as the first LD pull-through was described in 1994."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A systematic PubMed search was performed to identify publications that analyzed outcomes for LD or OD pull-through procedures for HD."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "All studies assessing functional outcome for OD and/or LD procedures were analyzed for eligibility, including randomized control trials and observational studies."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Data collected included study characteristics (author, journal, publication year, sample size, length of follow-up, and operative technique) and patient demographics (sex and age at surgery)."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: "Their risk of bias was assessed and summarized."
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Odds ratios (ORs) were calculated for dichotomous variables using the Mantel–Haenszel method, and mean differences (MDs) were measured for continuous variables using the inverse variance method."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable.
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "From 11 articles 456 patients were included (253 OD, 203 LD), with no significant difference in age at surgery and length of follow-up (P > .05)."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Four hundred fifty-six patients with HD were included in this review (range, 20–76 patients per study)."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "The open group had a significantly greater incidence of soiling/incontinence (11% versus 4%; P = .02) and further surgery (25% versus 14%; P = .005), longer hospital stay (9.79 versus 7.3 days; P < .00001), and time to oral feed (4.05 versus 3.27 days; P < .00001). Operative time was significantly longer in the laparoscopic group (3.83 versus 4.09 hours; P = .004). There was no significant difference in incidence of enterocolitis (15% versus 10%; P = .14) and constipation (23% versus 30%; P = .12)."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Our meta-analysis proposes that LD pull-through is superior to OD pull-through for HD."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The results of our meta-analysis should be carefully interpreted. The following are unavoidable limitations: None of the studies included prospective data or randomized control trials."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Our meta-analysis proposes that LD pull-through is superior to OD pull-through for HD. The laparoscopic technique resulted in a significantly reduced incidence of postoperative soiling/incontinence and a reduced requirement for further surgery."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: "No competing financial interests exist."
[Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Treatment of Idiopathic Achalasia in the Pediatric Population: A Systematic Review" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "Background Achalasia is a rare idiopathic neuromuscular disorder of the esophagus, characterized as a syndrome of impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter and decreased peristalsis of the esophageal body." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Achalasia is a rare neuromuscular disorder of the esophagus, characterized as a syndrome of impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and decreased peristalsis of the esophageal body." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The primary objective is to determine the best first-line treatment for pediatric achalasia based on the consolidation of the current literature that compares outcomes after pneumatic dilatation (PD) versus surgical myotomy (Heller esophagomyotomy [HM])." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: "The PRISMA format was used for the structure of this systematic review." [Yes]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Type of studies: Systematic reviews and retrospective reviews were included. There were no prospective randomized trials identified in the pediatric esophageal achalasia literature." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "Studies were identified by searching the electronic database MEDLINE (OVID), and by hand search of reference lists for further relevant articles." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: "Full abstracts of articles obtained by the OVID search were reviewed based on inclusion and exclusion criteria clearly delineated before the start of the review process." [Yes]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Full articles were then reviewed and screened. Examination of references was performed and additional articles were obtained for inclusion in the discussion." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: "We developed data sheet (Microsoft Excel 2000 9.0.6926 SP-3, Microsoft Corporation) for our outcome measures listed earlier." [Yes]
P11. Methods / Data items: "Primary and secondary outcomes measures listed earlier were extracted from each study." [Yes]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: "Reliability of each study was determined based on the level of evidence of each study, study design, number of patients enrolled, and length of follow-up." [Yes]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: "There may have been some adult studies that contained patients younger than 21 years inadvertently excluded by the OVID search methods delineated earlier." [Yes]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "The search of OVID database provided 103 citations." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "All seven studies selected for the review were dedicated pediatric retrospective reviews (level III evidence) published in English between the years of 1980 and 2010." [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: "There were four leaks after HM of which two were intraoperatively detected, one delayed and one nonspecified." [Yes]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "The best first-line treatment of pediatric achalasia was determined to be HM in two articles, PD in one article, and equal efficacy in one article." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "The optimal treatment algorithm for pediatric achalasia remains unclear as adequate comparative data between PD and HM are lacking." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "Achalasia is a rare disorder resulting in small sample size which is further compounded by stratification of subjects into even smaller treatment groups." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "The optimal treatment algorithm for pediatric achalasia remains unclear as adequate comparative data between PD and HM are lacking." [Yes]
P27. Funding: "No funding was used." [Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "The management of postoperative reflux in congenital esophageal atresia–tracheoesophageal fistula: a systematic review" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We performed a systematic review of the literature regarding routine anti-reflux medication post EA-TEF repair and its impact on postoperative GER and associated complications." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Esophageal atresia (EA), with or without tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF), is associated with postoperative gastroesophageal reflux (GER)." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The objective of this study was to determine the prevalence of anti-reflux medication use in postoperative EA-TEF patients, and the impact of routine anti-reflux medication on postoperative GER and its associated complications." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Studies were included if they fulfilled the following criteria: (1) published between inception of database and November 2012, (2) primary diagnosis of EA with or without TEF, (3) secondary diagnosis of postoperative GER, (4) primary treatment for GER with anti-reflux medications (not limited by type of agent, dose or mode of delivery)." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "A comprehensive search was conducted using MEDLINE/PubMed, CINHAL, EMBASE/OVID, and CENTRAL (the Cochrane library) electronic databases." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: Not reported [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Title and abstract screening was carried out independently and in duplicate." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Data abstraction was performed in duplicate and verified for accuracy and quality via a pre-piloted standardized data abstraction form; discrepancies were resolved by consensus." [Yes]
P11. Methods / Data items: "The primary outcome of the success of prophylactic reflux medication on decreasing rates of GER was analyzed based on a reported postoperative decrease in gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms, decrease in respiratory symptoms or demonstrable weight gain." [Yes]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Descriptive analyses including counts, percentages, means and standard deviations where appropriate were employed." [Yes]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "There were 2,910 potential citations identified through database searches. Of these, 25 papers (1,663 eligible patients) were eligible for inclusion and final analysis." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "All studies were small (mean number of included patients 55.4, SD 51.34 (median 61.00, min 5, max 210)." [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "The majority of papers in this review were small, retrospective unmatched cohort studies based on single-center experiences and prone to the bias that accompanies small observational studies." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "The published literature regarding empiric anti-reflux therapy in infants with EA-TEF is of a low level of evidence and suffers from a lack of standardization." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The majority of papers in this review were small, retrospective unmatched cohort studies based on single-center experiences and prone to the bias that accompanies small observational studies." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Consistent and reliable outcome reporting including definitions of outcomes, best diagnostic criteria, use of reporting checklists for study design and reporting, and adequate follow-up will be necessary for the development of treatment guidelines." [Yes]
P27. Funding: "None." [Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Laparoscopic versus open surgery in children with choledochal cysts: a meta-analysis"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "To compare the safety and efficacy between laparoscopic and open cyst excision with hepaticojejunostomy for children with choledochal cysts using meta-analysis."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The optimal definitive treatment is complete excision of cysts with Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. Laparoscopic excision of choledochal cysts has increasingly gained acceptance and applicability since its first description by Farello."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To compare the safety and efficacy between laparoscopic and open cyst excision with hepaticojejunostomy for children with choledochal cysts using meta-analysis."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "The studies that published up to and including November 2014 were considered eligible if they met the following inclusion criteria: (1) study reported on at least one of the outcome measures mentioned below: operative time, intraoperative blood loss, time to food intake, postoperative morbidity (including bile leakage, pancreatic leakage, cholangitis, pancreatitis, adhesive intestinal obstruction, abdominal bleeding, etc.,) and mortality, length of hospital stay; (2) population: children younger than 18 years with choledochal cysts; (3) intervention: laparoscopic cyst excision and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy (LH) versus open cyst excision and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy (OH)."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "We searched databases, including PubMed, Embase, the Science Citation Index, and Cochrane Library updated to November 2014, to identify all related published studies comparing the laparoscopic and the open choledochal cyst excision with hepaticojejunostomy. The keywords used in the search were as follows: laparoscopic, open, hepaticojejunostomy, choledochal cysts."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Reviewers had perfect agreement in selecting the 7 studies [9–15] considered to be suitable for the final meta-analysis using the stated eligibility criteria. All 7 included studies are retrospective series."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Two reviewers (Huo-Jian Shen and Ming Xu) abstracted relevant information from each eligible article using a standardized form independently."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: "Information about the characteristics of the study population, authors, publication year, study period, country, sample size, interventions, outcomes details of the surgical techniques used, and relevant outcomes were recorded."
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
[NA]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Outcomes were calculated as odds ratios (ORs) with 95 % confidence intervals (CIs) using RevMan 5.2."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "According to the search strategy described previously, a total of 162 citations were obtained for review of title and abstract. Of the 162 citations, 14 duplicates were removed by the Endnote X5 software, and 131 irrelevant studies were excluded through scanning titles and abstracts. Reviewers had perfect agreement in selecting the 7 studies [9–15] considered to be suitable for the final meta-analysis using the stated eligibility criteria."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "All 7 included studies are retrospective series. They included total of 1016 patients. Of these, 408 (40.16 %) underwent LH, and 608 (59.84 %) had OH."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "In LH group compared with OH group, the operative time was longer, while the length of postoperative hospital stay was less, the intraoperative blood loss was lower and time to food intake was less. The rate of postoperative morbidity was more in the OH group, but there is no statistically significant difference between the two groups in postoperative morbidity."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Laparoscopic cyst excision with Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy is a safe and effective treatment option for choledochal cysts in children with comparable outcomes to open resection."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "This meta-analysis has some limitations that should be taken into account when considering the results. First, there are no randomized trials comparing the two procedures. Second, except one study [14], the others did not compare outcomes between the laparoscopic and open group within the same study period. Third, in some studies, the number of patients was too small, leading to low-power analyses. At last, heterogeneity among the studies is high."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Laparoscopic cyst excision with Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy is a safe and effective treatment option for choledochal cysts in children with comparable outcomes to open resection."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: Not reported.
[No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "[A meta-analysis of outcomes after open and laparoscopic Nissen’s fundoplication for gastro-oesophageal reflux disease in children]"
Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a meta-analysis of outcomes after open and laparoscopic Nissen's fundoplication for gastro-oesophageal reflux disease in children.
Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The objective of this study is to meta-analyse the published literature comparing outcomes after open (ONF) versus laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication (LNF) for gastro-oesophageal reflux disease in children."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including the background, objectives, and study eligibility criteria.
Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) may cause symptoms in up to 7% of children. In older children, symptoms may present as heartburn or dysphagia. In neonates and infants, failure to thrive and respiratory complications may ensue."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about gastro-oesophageal reflux disease in children.
Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The objective of this study is to meta-analyse the published literature comparing outcomes after open (ONF) versus laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication (LNF) for gastro-oesophageal reflux disease in children."
Reasoning: The objectives of the study are explicitly stated, including the participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design.
Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not mentioned in the full text.
Reasoning: The full text does not mention whether a review protocol exists or provide any information about registration.
Response: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "All comparative studies investigating LNF versus ONF for GORD in children between January 1993 and October 2009 were identified."
Reasoning: The study clearly specifies the study characteristics (comparative studies investigating LNF versus ONF for GORD in children) and report characteristics (years considered) used as eligibility criteria.
Response: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "We searched the MEDLINE, EMBASE and CINAHL available through the National Library of Health website, the Cochrane library and PubMed databases available online."
Reasoning: The information sources used for the search are described.
Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: "The text words 'minimally invasive', 'keyhole surgery', 'heartburn', 'reflux disease' and 'children' were used in combination with the medical subject headings 'laparoscopy', 'fundoplication' and 'gastro-oesophageal reflux'."
Reasoning: The full electronic search strategy is provided, including the keywords and medical subject headings used.
Response: [Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Each article was critically reviewed by two researchers using a double extraction method for eligibility in our review. This was performed independently and any conflict resolved prior to final analysis."
Reasoning: The process for selecting studies is described, including screening, eligibility, and inclusion in the systematic review.
Response: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Each article was critically reviewed by two researchers using a double extraction method for eligibility in our review. This was performed independently and any conflict resolved prior to final analysis."
Reasoning: The method of data extraction from reports is described, including the use of a double extraction method by two researchers.
Response: [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: "Outcome variables were operative time, hospital stay, feed time, morbidity and recurrence."
Reasoning: The data items for which data were sought are listed, including the outcome variables.
Response: [Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not mentioned in the full text.
Reasoning: The full text does not describe the methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies.
Response: [No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "For continuous data (operation time, hospital stay and time to feeding), Hedges g statistic was used for the calculation of standardized mean differences (SMDs). Binary data (morbidity and recurrence) were summarized as risk ratios (RR)."
Reasoning: The principal summary measures used in the meta-analysis are stated, including the use of Hedges g statistic for continuous data and risk ratios for binary data.
Response: [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
Reasoning: Since no meta-analysis was performed, this item is not applicable.
Response: [NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
Reasoning: Since no meta-analysis was performed, this item is not applicable.
Response: [NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no additional analyses performed).
Reasoning: Since no additional analyses were performed, this item is not applicable.
Response: [NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "Twelve studies discussing LNF were retrieved from the electronic databases. Six studies were included in our study according to our inclusion criteria."
Reasoning: The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are given, along with reasons for exclusions.
Response: [Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "There were 466 patients in the laparoscopic group and 255 in the open group."
Reasoning: The characteristics for each study are presented, including the number of patients in each group.
Response: [Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not mentioned in the full text.
Reasoning: The full text does not present data on the risk of bias of each study.
Response: [No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Children stayed in hospital for less time after undergoing LNF compared with ONF. Children feed earlier after LNF and had less morbidity. No difference in recurrence at 12 months was highlighted."
Reasoning: The results of individual studies are presented, including the outcomes of hospital stay, feed time, morbidity, and recurrence.
Response: [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
Reasoning: Since no meta-analysis was performed, this item is not applicable.
Response: [NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
Reasoning: Since no meta-analysis was performed, this item is not applicable.
Response: [NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no additional analyses performed).
Reasoning: Since no additional analyses were performed, this item is not applicable.
Response: [NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "LNF is superior to ONF in relation to feeding, hospital stay and morbidity and is comparable to ONF in terms of operative time and recurrence."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "Limitations to our meta-analysis include lack of clear definitions in individual studies relating to operative time, morbidity and feeding regimens. Different ages of patients may cloud definitive conclusions."
Reasoning: The limitations of the study are discussed, including the lack of clear definitions in individual studies and the potential impact of different ages of patients on the conclusions.
Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "LNF may be considered as a first line operative technique when expertise is available; however, larger comparative series focusing on short and long outcomes are required to strengthen the evidence."
Reasoning: A general interpretation of the results is provided in the context of other evidence, along with implications for future research.
Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: "None."
Reasoning: The sources of funding for the systematic review and other support are described.
Response: [Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Laparoscopic Versus Open Reduction of Intussusception in Children: A Retrospective Review and Meta-analysis"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We performed a retrospective review of all children with intussusception who required operative reduction at our institution over a 12-year time period. We also performed a meta-analysis to combine our data with the published literature."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Controversy exists as to whether the laparoscopic (LAP) operative approach is as safe and effective as the standard open approach."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "We aimed to retrospectively review our institution's experience with the surgical treatment of intussusception, comparing the LAP and open approaches. Second, we sought to conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis, combining our data with existing literature, in order to identify any differences in outcome measures across all identified comparative studies."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "We retrospectively reviewed the electronic and paper charts of all patients requiring operative intervention for intussusception."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "Two researchers independently searched the electronic databases MEDLINE, Embase, CINAHL, and the Cochrane Library."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Two researchers independently screened the title and abstract of identified articles for potential eligibility and retrieved the full-text version of all articles deemed relevant."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "We retrospectively reviewed the electronic and paper charts of all patients requiring operative intervention for intussusception."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "We analyzed continuous data as weighted mean differences and dichotomous outcomes as odds ratios, using 95% confidence intervals for all analyses."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: [NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: [NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: [NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "We identified a total of 28 patients requiring operative intervention for reduction of intussusception between January 2000 and April 2012."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The demographics and outcomes of both groups are presented in Table 1."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Our meta-analysis identified five retrospective studies comparing LAP and open techniques for reduction of intussusception."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: [NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: [NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: [NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Our data suggest that LAP reduction of intussusception is as technically feasible, safe, and efficacious as the open approach and may even be beneficial in shortening LOS."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The current literature on this topic is limited to retrospective studies, which are inherently limited by methodological bias."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Our data suggest that LAP reduction of intussusception is as technically feasible, safe, and efficacious as the open approach and may even be beneficial in shortening LOS."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: "No competing financial interests exist."
[Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Peritoneal Drainage versus Laparotomy for Necrotizing Enterocolitis and Intestinal Perforation: A Meta-Analysis"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "To determine whether peritoneal drain (PD) or laparotomy (LAP) is the most effective intervention in premature neonates with necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) or intestinal perforation (IP)."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The surgical management of premature neonates with necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) or isolated intestinal perforation (IP) remains controversial."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To determine whether peritoneal drain (PD) or laparotomy (LAP) is the most effective intervention in premature neonates with necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) or intestinal perforation (IP)."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Studies that evaluated only neonates with NEC and IP treated with either LAP (control) or PD (experimental treatment) were selected."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "The Ovid (Ovid Technologies New York, NY) and Medline search engines were used to examine both the Pubmed and Cochrane libraries from January 2000 to December 2008."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Prospective studies, including randomized and nonrandomized designs, with a minimum of 25 patients allocated in each of the treatment and control arms, were considered in this systematic review."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Two reviewers (JES, LGK), using a predefined data extraction form, extracted data from the publications related to gestational age, birth weight, type of operation, and mortality."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: [NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: [NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: [NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "Systematic review of the literature identified 12 trials that were potentially applicable for inclusion in the meta-analysis. Of these potential studies, five met selection criteria."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The sample size of the trials ranged from 65 to 156 patients per trial for a combined 523 participants for comparison of PD (273) and LAP (250)."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Mortality ranged in the LAP group from 15% to 43%, and from 35% to 54% in the PD group."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: [NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: [NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: [NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Our systematic review of prospective studies from January 2000 to December 2008 demonstrated that PD was associated with a statistically significant excess mortality of 55%."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The first relates to the validity in the application of meta-analysis to answer this question. In addition, differences in inclusion criteria with regards to birth weight (<1000 g versus < 1500 g) and presence of pneumoperitoneum, treatment protocols, and postoperative care exist across the trials."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Review of the five prospective studies from January 2000 to December 2008 refutes the hypothesis that PD is superior to LAP. In addition, this meta-analysis demonstrates a statistically significant excess mortality of 55% associated with PD."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: Not reported.
[No]

P1. Title: "Laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS) for major urological procedures in the pediatric population: A systematic review" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: No abstract or structured summary provided [No]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Improvements in laparoscopic surgery have led to the introduction of laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS) as an alternative to conventional laparoscopy conferring a number of possible advantages." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: No explicit statement of objectives provided [No]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No information on protocol or registration provided [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Studies investigating the technical aspects and clinical outcomes of partial nephrectomies, nephrectomies, nephroureterectomies, varicocelectomies and pyeloplasties in children." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "An in-depth search of the literature was performed in the databases of PubMed and Scopus." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: No full electronic search strategy provided [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Two reviewers working independently extracted data from all eligible studies." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: No information on data extraction process provided [No]
P11. Methods / Data items: No information on data items sought provided [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No information on risk of bias assessment provided [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: No information on summary measures provided [No]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "Twenty nine studies met the inclusion criteria incorporating 386 patients who underwent 401 procedures." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations." [No]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No information on risk of bias assessment provided [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot." [No]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable, as there is no additional analysis [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "In the hands of experienced surgeons LESS seems a feasible, efficient and less invasive alternative to standard laparoscopy in the field of pediatric urology." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "There is not enough evidence to support the superiority of LESS thus wide adoption cannot be recommended." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "There is an imperative need of well-designed prospective randomized trials, with large number of patients, in order to clarify the safety and long term efficacy of LESS for urological procedures in the pediatric population." [Yes]
P27. Funding: No information on funding provided [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Screening and Treatment of Intestinal Rotational Abnormalities in Heterotaxy: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
[Yes] The report is identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "To assess the role of screening and prophylactic surgery for intestinal rotational abnormalities (IRAs) in asymptomatic patients with heterotaxy."
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, and key findings.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Heterotaxy is a congenital anomaly characterized by abnormal cardiovisceral left-to-right axis arrangement."
[Yes] The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To assess the role of screening and prophylactic surgery for intestinal rotational abnormalities (IRAs) in asymptomatic patients with heterotaxy."
[Yes] The objectives of the review are explicitly stated.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No information provided.
[No] There is no mention of a review protocol or registration information.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "PubMed, Embase, and Cinahl were searched electronically to determine the overall incidence of IRAs in heterotaxy."
[Yes] The study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.

P7. Methods / Information sources: "PubMed, Embase, and Cinahl were searched electronically."
[Yes] The information sources are described.

P8. Methods / Search: "The search was limited to reports published after January 1, 1980."
[Yes] The full electronic search strategy is not provided, but the search limits are mentioned.

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Two authors reviewed all the abstracts independently."
[Yes] The process for selecting studies is described.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "The same 2 reviewers independently extracted relevant data on study characteristics and the outcomes of interest."
[Yes] The method of data extraction is described.

P11. Methods / Data items: No information provided.
[No] There is no mention of the variables for which data were sought.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No information provided.
[No] There is no mention of the methods used for assessing risk of bias.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Meta-analyses of proportions were performed to combine the data."
[Yes] The principal summary measures are stated.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: No information provided.
[NA] Not applicable since there is no meta-analysis.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: No information provided.
[NA] Not applicable since there is no meta-analysis.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: No information provided.
[NA] Not applicable since there is no additional analysis.

P17. Results / Study selection: "A total of 24 studies met inclusion criteria for the systematic review."
[Yes] The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are provided.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "24 studies with a total of 1433 patients with heterotaxy were included for systematic review."
[Yes] The characteristics of the included studies are presented.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No information provided.
[No] There is no mention of the risk of bias within studies.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "The screen-detected incidences of IRA and acute midgut volvulus were significantly greater in heterotaxy than the normal population."
[Yes] The results of individual studies are presented.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: No information provided.
[NA] Not applicable since there is no meta-analysis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: No information provided.
[NA] Not applicable since there is no meta-analysis.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: No information provided.
[NA] Not applicable since there is no additional analysis.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "The screen-detected incidences of IRA and acute midgut volvulus were significantly greater in heterotaxy than the normal population."
[Yes] The main findings are summarized.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The selected studies consisted of disparate populations of varied study period with patients treated as far back as 1968."
[Yes] The limitations of the study are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "A prospective randomized controlled trial is needed to define the gold standard approach."
[Yes] The general interpretation of the results and implications for future research are provided.

P27. Funding: "We thank Karen John-Pierre and Cathryn Peppard (NHS Liaison Librarian, St George's University of London) for contributing to the literature search for systematic review."
[Yes] The sources of funding for the systematic review and other support are described.

Overall, 19 out of 27 PRISMA items were reported, 6 items were not reported, and 2 items were not applicable.

P17. Results / Study selection: "A total of 24 studies met inclusion criteria for the systematic review."
[Yes] The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are provided.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "24 studies with a total of 1433 patients with heterotaxy were included for systematic review."
[Yes] The characteristics of the included studies are presented.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No information provided.
[No] There is no mention of the risk of bias within studies.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "The screen-detected incidences of IRA and acute midgut volvulus were significantly greater in heterotaxy than the normal population."
[Yes] The results of individual studies are presented.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: No information provided.
[NA] Not applicable since there is no meta-analysis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: No information provided.
[NA] Not applicable since there is no meta-analysis.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: No information provided.
[NA] Not applicable since there is no additional analysis.

[Yes] The main findings are summarized.

[Yes] The limitations of the study are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "A prospective randomized controlled trial is needed to define the gold standard approach."
[Yes] The general interpretation of the results and implications for future research are provided.

P27. Funding: "We thank Karen John-Pierre and Cathryn Peppard (NHS Liaison Librarian, St George's University of London) for contributing to the literature search for systematic review."
[Yes] The sources of funding for the systematic review and other support are described.

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Surgical approaches for neonatal congenital diaphragmatic hernia: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
[Yes] The report is identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of the effectiveness of endoscopic surgery (ES) for neonatal CDH."
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, and results.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The optimal surgical approach for neonatal congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) remains unclear."
[Yes] The rationale for the review is described in the introduction.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of the effectiveness of endoscopic surgery (ES) for neonatal CDH."
[Yes] The objectives of the review are explicitly stated.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No relevant quote found.
[No] No information is provided about a review protocol or registration.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Studies that compared surgical approaches for neonatal CDH were selected."
[Yes] The study characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A systematic literature search was conducted using MEDLINE and the Cochrane Library."
[Yes] The information sources are described.

P8. Methods / Search: "The articles were screened according to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) flow chart."
[Yes] The full electronic search strategy is not provided, but the use of the PRISMA flow chart is mentioned.

P9. Methods / Study selection: "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)."
[Yes] The process for selecting studies is not explicitly stated, but it can be inferred that studies were screened for eligibility and included in the systematic review.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Two individual authors extracted data from each selected study."
[Yes] The method of data extraction is described.

P11. Methods / Data items: "The following items were collected: (1) authors’ names and year of publication, (2) title of the published study, (3) journal in which the study was published, (4) country and year of the study, (5) whether the study was single-center or multicenter, (6) whether the study had a prospective or retrospective design, (7) testing sample size, (8) patient age, (9) whether consecutive patients were included, (10) surgical approaches in both arms of the trial, (11) method of assigning patients to the two groups, (12) number of patients receiving each surgical approach, (13) number of patients who failed the allocated treatment (conversion to OS), (14) postoperative follow-up period, (15) number of postoperative deaths, and (16) number of patients who developed recurrence."
[Yes] The data items for which data were sought are listed and defined.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: "As assessed on the GRADE scale, the quality of evidence was very low for all outcomes."
[Yes] The methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies are described.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Risk ratios (RRs) and 95 % confidential intervals (CIs) were determined using RevMan 5.3 software."
[Yes] The principal summary measures are stated.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable since there is no meta-analysis.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable since there is no assessment of risk of bias across studies.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable since there are no additional analyses.

P17. Results / Study selection: "Of 264 search results, 226 studies were excluded based on titles and abstracts. After screening the remaining 38 studies based on their full texts, 14 studies were included in the qualitative synthesis."
[Yes] The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are given.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The eight observational studies were included in a quantitative synthesis."
[Yes] The characteristics of the included studies are presented.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: "As assessed on the GRADE scale, the quality of evidence was very low for all outcomes."
[Yes] Data on risk of bias of each study are presented.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "The ES group showed both a significantly lower mortality rate and a significantly higher recurrence rate compared to the OS group."
[Yes] The results of individual studies are presented.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable since there is no meta-analysis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable since there is no assessment of risk of bias across studies.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable since there are no additional analyses.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Although the evidence was insufficient, ES was clearly associated with more recurrence than was OS."
[Yes] The main findings are summarized.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The quality of evidence was very low for all outcomes, mainly as a product of selection bias and other methodological limitations."
[Yes] The limitations of the review are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "ES should not be the routine treatment for every neonate. It is crucially important to select suitable cases for ES."
[Yes] A general interpretation of the results and implications for future research are provided.

P27. Funding: "This work was supported by a grant from the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan."
[Yes] The sources of funding for the systematic review are described.

Overall, 24 out of 27 PRISMA items were reported in the full text. The items not reported are P5 (Methods / Protocol and registration), P14 (Methods / Synthesis of results), and P15 (Methods / Risk of bias across studies), which are not applicable in the context of this systematic review without a meta-analysis.
