llm_message:
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
[Yes] "Laparoscopic versus open inguinal herniotomy in infants and children: a meta-analysis"

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
[Yes] The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
[Yes] The introduction provides an explicit statement of the questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
[No] No information is provided about the existence of a review protocol or registration.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
[Yes] The methods specify the study characteristics (PICOS) and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
[Yes] The methods describe the information sources (databases with dates of coverage) in the search and the date last searched.

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
[No] No information is provided about the full electronic search strategy.

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
[Yes] The methods state the process for selecting studies, including screening, eligibility, and inclusion in the systematic review.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
[Yes] The methods describe the method of data extraction from reports and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
[Yes] The methods list and define the variables for which data were sought.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
[Yes] The methods describe the methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
[Yes] The methods state the principal summary measures.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
[Yes] The results give the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
[Yes] The results present characteristics for each study and provide the citations.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
[Yes] The results present data on the risk of bias of each study.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
[Yes] The results present simple summary data for each intervention group for all outcomes considered.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
[Yes] The discussion summarizes the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome and considers their relevance to key groups.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
[Yes] The discussion discusses limitations at the study and outcome level and at the review-level.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
[Yes] The discussion provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
[No] No information is provided about the sources of funding for the systematic review and other support.
original_llm_message:
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
[Yes] "Laparoscopic versus open inguinal herniotomy in infants and children: a meta-analysis"

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
[Yes] The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
[Yes] The introduction provides an explicit statement of the questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
[No] No information is provided about the existence of a review protocol or registration.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
[Yes] The methods specify the study characteristics (PICOS) and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
[Yes] The methods describe the information sources (databases with dates of coverage) in the search and the date last searched.

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
[No] No information is provided about the full electronic search strategy.

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
[Yes] The methods state the process for selecting studies, including screening, eligibility, and inclusion in the systematic review.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
[Yes] The methods describe the method of data extraction from reports and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
[Yes] The methods list and define the variables for which data were sought.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
[Yes] The methods describe the methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
[Yes] The methods state the principal summary measures.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
[Yes] The results give the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
[Yes] The results present characteristics for each study and provide the citations.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
[Yes] The results present data on the risk of bias of each study.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
[Yes] The results present simple summary data for each intervention group for all outcomes considered.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
[Yes] The discussion summarizes the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome and considers their relevance to key groups.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
[Yes] The discussion discusses limitations at the study and outcome level and at the review-level.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
[Yes] The discussion provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
[No] No information is provided about the sources of funding for the systematic review and other support.

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Management of Recurrent Tracheoesophageal Fistulas: A Systematic Review" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We aim to comparatively review all published treatment options, and outcomes, for managing RTEF." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The ideal approach to the management of recurrent tracheoesophageal fistulas (RTEF) is still in debate." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "We aim to comparatively review all published treatment options, and outcomes, for managing RTEF." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of design, describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: Not reported [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of design, describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: Not reported [No]
P11. Methods / Data items: "The data obtained included number of patients treated, treatment modality employed, effectiveness of each treatment modality, and the outcomes after treatment." [Yes]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported [NA]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not reported [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not reported [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "A total of 23 papers between 1984 and 2012 described 57 patients undergoing some form of endoscopic treatment (ET) while 21 papers between 1955 and 2013 described 108 patients that underwent an open surgical repair." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "A total of 165 cases of RTEF are described and there were 44 (26.7%) cases associated with anastomotic leaks while 35 (21.2%) were associated with anastomotic strictures preceding the diagnosis of RTEF." [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Of the 57 ET patients, there was an 84% success rate compared with 93.5% of 108 OS patients." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not reported [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not reported [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "OS for RTEF has a low morbidity and mortality, a higher success rate, and requires fewer treatments than an endoscopic repair." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The main limitations of this review include the heterogeneity of the included articles, particularly as case reports would predominantly report positive outcomes." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "OS for the repair of recurrent TEF has a low morbidity, mortality, and re-fistulation rate particularly when an interposition tissue is placed between the trachea and esophagus. We recommend OS as the treatment of choice when faced with a recurrent TEF." [Yes]
P27. Funding: Not reported [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Pediatric Surgical Technique: Laparoscopic or Open Approach? A systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "This review was conducted to compare the clinical and cost effectiveness of laparoscopic and open surgical approaches for a variety of surgical indications in pediatric populations."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "This review was conducted to evaluate the clinical and cost-effectiveness of this approach for a variety of different surgical indications in pediatric populations."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To evaluate the clinical and cost-effectiveness of laparoscopic and open techniques in pediatric populations."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Inclusion criteria: Prospective randomized or prospective non-randomized study format only. Operative results reported for a “pediatric population”, using the words “children, infants or neonates” to describe the study group and including infants, neonates or children (or combinations of the three). Study subjects under 17 years of age only. Comparison of laparoscopic and open techniques. Report on at least one of the outcome measures mentioned previously."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "All available electronic databases including the British Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIOSIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and IgentaConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992–2009 for all English and non–English language articles."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Each article was independently assessed for eligibility using the following criteria: Prospective randomized or prospective non-randomized study format only. Operative results reported for a “pediatric population”, using the words “children, infants or neonates” to describe the study group and including infants, neonates or children (or combinations of the three). Study subjects under 17 years of age only. Comparison of laparoscopic and open techniques. Report on at least one of the outcome measures mentioned previously."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Not reported.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Weighted mean differences (WMD) were used as the summary statistic, comparing the laparoscopic treatment groups with the reference (open surgery) groups using the Mantel-Haenszel method."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis).
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis).
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no meta-analysis).
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: Not reported.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "LOS was found to be significantly reduced in favor of the laparoscopic approach, with a weighted mean difference of −1.44 days, although the OR time was significantly increased, with a weighted mean difference of +12.8 min. Laparoscopic intervention was associated with a significantly reduced complication rate compared to the open approach (10.6 vs. 15.6%). Total hospital costs of the laparoscopic approaches were found to be insignificantly increased compared to the open techniques."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis).
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis).
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no meta-analysis).
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "This review strengthens the use of MIS in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three laparoscopic procedures reviewed showed better patient outcomes compared to open procedures in the form of reduced LOS and complication rates."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The validity of the results of this review largely depends on the validity of the included studies. Many of the included studies failed to take all the steps necessary to avoid bias. There may well be an inherent bias in the analyses, which are likely to favor the ‘newer’ MIS/laparoscopic technique."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "This review further supports the use of minimally invasive surgery (MIS) in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three types laparoscopic procedures reviewed resulted in better patient outcomes compared to open procedures, in the form of reduced LOS and overall complication rates."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: "Conflict of interest: None"
[Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
1. Quote: "Bariatric surgery for obese children and adolescents: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
2. Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
3. Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
1. Quote: "We aimed to (i) systematically review the literature on bariatric surgery in children and adolescents; (ii) meta-analyse change in body mass index (BMI) 1-year post-surgery and (iii) report complications, co-morbidity resolution and health-related quality of life (HRQoL)."
2. Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.
3. Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
1. Quote: "The global prevalence of obesity is rising in children and adolescents."
2. Reasoning: The introduction provides the rationale for the review by highlighting the increasing prevalence of obesity in children and adolescents.
3. Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
1. Quote: "We aimed to (i) systematically review the literature on bariatric surgery in children and adolescents; (ii) meta-analyse change in body mass index (BMI) 1-year post-surgery and (iii) report complications, co-morbidity resolution and health-related quality of life (HRQoL)."
2. Reasoning: The objectives are explicitly stated, including the participants (children and adolescents), interventions (bariatric surgery), outcomes (change in BMI, complications, co-morbidity resolution, HRQoL), and study design (systematic review and meta-analysis).
3. Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
1. Quote: No information provided.
2. Reasoning: There is no mention of a review protocol or registration information.
3. Response: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
1. Quote: "Studies were included if (i) they assessed BMI before and a minimum of six months after individuals predominately received AGB, RYGB, BPD or SG and (ii) the mean age of the population was between 6 and 18 years at study entry."
2. Reasoning: The eligibility criteria are specified, including the study characteristics (assessment of BMI before and after surgery) and the report characteristics (age of the population).
3. Response: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
1. Quote: "The indexed reference libraries EMBASE and Medline were searched between January 1955 and January 2013 using the search terms presented in Table 1, using mapped and exploded terms."
2. Reasoning: The information sources are described, including the databases (EMBASE and Medline) and the dates of coverage.
3. Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
1. Quote: "Search terms for EMBASE and Medline via Ovid SP"
2. Reasoning: The search strategy is mentioned, but the full electronic search strategy is not provided.
3. Response: [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
1. Quote: "Two authors independently screened the abstracts and extraction was verified by a second author (JAB and RKS)."
2. Reasoning: The process for selecting studies is described, including screening the abstracts and verification of extraction by a second author.
3. Response: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
1. Quote: "We used a standard data extraction method to collect the following information on each study: years during which the surgery was performed, authors, country, study design, mean age and variance of study participants, type of surgery, gender distribution, complications, co-morbidities, pre-/post-surgery BMI with variance, number of participants, length of follow-up and loss to follow-up."
2. Reasoning: The method of data extraction is described, including the information collected from each study.
3. Response: [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
1. Quote: "We used a standard data extraction method to collect the following information on each study: years during which the surgery was performed, authors, country, study design, mean age and variance of study participants, type of surgery, gender distribution, complications, co-morbidities, pre-/post-surgery BMI with variance, number of participants, length of follow-up and loss to follow-up."
2. Reasoning: The variables for which data were sought are listed, including the study characteristics (years during which the surgery was performed, authors, country, study design, mean age and variance of study participants, type of surgery, gender distribution) and the outcomes (complications, co-morbidities, pre-/post-surgery BMI with variance, number of participants, length of follow-up and loss to follow-up).
3. Response: [Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
1. Quote: No information provided.
2. Reasoning: There is no mention of methods used for assessing risk of bias or how this information is used in data synthesis.
3. Response: [No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
1. Quote: "The summary effect measure of unstandardized change in BMI at the time point closest to 12 months post-surgery was produced using the DerSimonian and Laird random effects method."
2. Reasoning: The principal summary measure (unstandardized change in BMI) is stated.
3. Response: [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
1. Quote: No information provided.
2. Reasoning: There is no mention of the methods of handling data and combining results of studies or measures of consistency.
3. Response: [NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
1. Quote: No information provided.
2. Reasoning: There is no mention of any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
3. Response: [NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
1. Quote: No information provided.
2. Reasoning: There is no mention of any additional analyses.
3. Response: [NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
1. Quote: "A total of 2303 unique citations were returned by the search strategy (Fig. 1). Of these, 2185 were excluded based on abstract review."
2. Reasoning: The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are provided, along with the reasons for exclusions at each stage.
3. Response: [Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
1. Quote: "A total of 54 papers met the inclusion criteria, representing 23 unique study populations."
2. Reasoning: The number of papers meeting the inclusion criteria and the number of unique study populations are provided.
3. Response: [Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
1. Quote: No information provided.
2. Reasoning: There is no mention of data on risk of bias within studies.
3. Response: [NA]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
1. Quote: "Mean BMI at baseline ranged from 38.5 to 60.2 kg m−2 (mean 47.9 kg m−2), and at follow-up from 25.2 to 41.5 kg m−2 (mean 34.7 kg m−2). All studies reported decreases in BMI."
2. Reasoning: The results of individual studies are presented, including the mean BMI at baseline and follow-up, and the fact that all studies reported decreases in BMI.
3. Response: [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
1. Quote: No information provided.
2. Reasoning: There is no mention of any meta-analysis done or the presentation of results.
3. Response: [NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
1. Quote: No information provided.
2. Reasoning: There is no mention of any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
3. Response: [NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
1. Quote: No information provided.
2. Reasoning: There is no mention of any additional analyses.
3. Response: [NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
1. Quote: "Bariatric surgery in adolescents results in similar short-term weight outcomes to adults, with RYGB producing the greatest weight loss with the most robust evidence base."
2. Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
3. Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
1. Quote: "The potential exists that the benefits of bariatric surgery have been inflated in the literature presented in this systematic review, as there were very few fixed study protocols before data collection and only clinics with promising records might have been incentivized to publish their data."
2. Reasoning: The limitations are discussed, including the potential for inflated benefits due to publication bias.
3. Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
1. Quote: "Current guidelines suggest that paediatric-adolescent bariatric care should be handled within the controlled and restricted setting of a multidisciplinary team."
2. Reasoning: The general interpretation of the results and implications for future research are provided.
3. Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
1. Quote: No information provided.
2. Reasoning: There is no mention of funding sources or other support.
3. Response: [No]

2. Reasoning: The limitations are discussed, including the potential for inflated benefits due to publication bias.
3. Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
1. Quote: "Current guidelines suggest that paediatric-adolescent bariatric care should be handled within the controlled and restricted setting of a multidisciplinary team."
2. Reasoning: The general interpretation of the results and implications for future research are provided.

1. Quote: No information provided.

P1. Title: "Laparoscopic vs open varicocelectomy in children and adolescents: review of the recent literature and meta-analysis"
[Yes] The report is identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "Meta-analysis and literature analysis showed that the results after laparoscopic varicocelectomy are comparable to other surgical procedures."
[Yes] The abstract provides a summary of the background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions of the review.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Varicocele is generally considered the most common correctable cause of male infertility. It is indicated as a factor in about one third of infertile males, being associated with testicular atrophy and abnormal seminal factors."
[Yes] The rationale for the review is provided in the introduction.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The aim of our study is to identify clinical evidence on the reliability of the laparoscopic technique compared to the open techniques, with the end points of recurrence rate and hydrocele formation."
[Yes] The objectives of the review are explicitly stated.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No] There is no mention of a review protocol or registration information.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Articles with data regarding recurrence, complications (hydrocele, hypotrophy, atrophy), and, if available, semen parameters after treatment were analyzed."
[Yes] The study and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A literature search was performed, using Medline and Pubmed database, on all articles published during the last 10 years (2000-2009), reporting on varicocele treatments."
[Yes] The information sources are described.

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No] The full electronic search strategy is not provided.

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Eleven studies published between 2000 and 2009 matched the inclusion criteria, comparing varicocele treatments in the pediatric population, and reporting the incidence of complications."
[Yes] The process for selecting studies is described.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "The results of continuous variables were reported as mean ± SD, and the statistical difference was calculated using the Student's t test. The statistical difference of percentages was calculated by Pearson's χ2."
[Yes] The method of data extraction and statistical analysis is described.

P11. Methods / Data items: "Articles with data regarding recurrence, complications (hydrocele, hypotrophy, atrophy), and, if available, semen parameters after treatment were analyzed."
[Yes] The variables for which data were sought are listed.

[NA] Risk of bias assessment is not applicable in the context of this review without a meta-analysis.

[NA] Synthesis of results is not applicable in the context of this review without a meta-analysis.

[NA] Additional analyses are not applicable in the context of this review without a meta-analysis.

[Yes] The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are provided.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Of the studies analyzed, we found 5 multicentric studies, 4 randomized trials, and 2 clinical trials."
[Yes] The characteristics of the included studies are presented.

[NA] Risk of bias assessment within studies is not reported.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "The results, globally considered, demonstrated a recurrence rate of 4.7% and hydrocele formation in 9.5% of patients."
[Yes] The results of individual studies are presented.

[Yes] The main findings and the strength of evidence are summarized.

[Yes] Limitations at study and outcome level are discussed.

[Yes] A general interpretation of the results and implications for future research are provided.

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Surgical Management of Primary Severe Hypospadias in Children: Systematic 20-Year Review" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We systematically reviewed the literature published during the last 20 years on the treatment of primary proximal hypospadias associated with severe ventral curvature." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The present systematic review shows the weak evidence backing current management of primary severe hypospadias." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The aim of the present review was to assess the results of studies published during the last 20 years on the primary repair of severe hypospadias." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "We included in this review only series containing detailed results after primary repair of severe hypospadias or after curvature correction in patients with primary severe hypospadias." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "We reviewed studies published between 1990 and December 2009, searching for “hypospadias” in MEDLINE®/PubMed®, EMBASE®, Web of Science® and the Cochrane Library." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: Not reported [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Three doctors reviewed the abstracts. Articles relevant to the topic of the review were selected by consensus." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: Not reported [No]
P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported [No]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: <added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: <added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: <added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>
P17. Results / Study selection: "We identified 69 studies for review." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: Not reported [No]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "We first reviewed the results of the different straightening procedures, then the crude complication rates (overall complication, fistula/dehiscence, stricture/stenosis rates) of the different urethroplasty techniques." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: <added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: <added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>
P23. Results / Additional analysis: <added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "The present review illustrates that there is an extreme paucity of studies to address in an evidence-based manner many of the common issues related to the primary repair of proximal hypospadias." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "An important limitation is that this review did not account for some variables such as age at surgery, use of additional coverage of urethroplasty, and type of preoperative and postoperative drainage and care." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "This systematic review demonstrates the weak evidence supporting current management of primary severe hyposapdias." [Yes]
P27. Funding: Not reported [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Does Preputial Reconstruction Increase Complication Rate of Hypospadias Repair? 20-Year Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
[Yes] The report is identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We performed a systematic review of the literature on preputial reconstruction (PR) during hypospadias repair to determine the cumulative risk of preputial skin complications and the influence of PR on urethroplasty complications, namely, fistula formation and overall reoperation rate of the repair."
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, and key findings.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Preputial asymmetry is one of the components of hypospadias. The prepuce stands like a hood over the glans penis, open ventrally, and redundant dorsally. Preputial reconstruction (PR) is an option during hypospadias repair, but many surgeons favor circumcision for the concern that PR might increase the complication rate of hypospadias repair."
[Yes] The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "We performed a systematic review of the literature on PR during hypospadias repair to determine the cumulative risk of specific complications related to the procedure. Moreover, we performed a meta-analysis of studies comparing urethroplasty complications and reoperation rates in patients undergoing hypospadias repair associated with PR vs. circumcision."
[Yes] The objectives of the review are explicitly stated.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No] There is no mention of a review protocol or registration information.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Only studies on the outcome of PR in children, defined as dehiscence of the reconstructed prepuce or secondary phimosis needing circumcision, were selected."
[Yes] The study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A systematic search of the literature published after 06/1995 was performed in 06/2015 using the keyword 'hypospadias.'"
[Yes] The information sources and search strategy are described.

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No] The full electronic search strategy is not presented.

P9. Methods / Study selection: "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)."
[Yes] The process for selecting studies is not explicitly stated, but it can be inferred that studies were screened and included based on the eligibility criteria mentioned.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators."
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of data extraction or data collection process.

P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported.
[No] There is no mention of the variables for which data were sought.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
[No] There is no mention of the methods used for assessing risk of bias in individual studies.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means)."
[Yes] The principal summary measures are not explicitly stated, but it can be inferred that odds ratios were used based on the meta-analysis results.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not reported.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis conducted.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no assessment of risk of bias across studies.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not reported.
[NA] Not applicable as there are no additional analyses conducted.

P17. Results / Study selection: "Twenty studies were identified. Nineteen reported the outcome of PR in 2115 patients."
[Yes] The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are provided.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The 20 studies included 2215 patients undergoing preputial sparing hypospadias repair."
[Yes] Characteristics of the included studies are presented.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no assessment of risk of bias within studies.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "A meta-analysis of seven studies comparing patients undergoing PR vs. circumcision showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation associated with PR."
[Yes] Results of individual studies are presented.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not reported.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis conducted.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no assessment of risk of bias across studies.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not reported.
[NA] Not applicable as there are no additional analyses conducted.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "This systematic review shows that according to available evidence PR carries an 8% risk of specific preputial complications, whereas it does not seem to increase the risk of urethroplasty complications and the overall reoperation rate of hypospadias repairs."
[Yes] The main findings and the strength of evidence are summarized.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "Results of systematic reviews are unavoidably dependent on the criteria chosen to select the studies and the quality of the studies included."
[Yes] Limitations of the review are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Preputial reconstruction is an option particularly in patients with distal hypospadias without associated penile curvature. It carries an 8% risk of specific complications, but does not seem to increase the risk of urethroplasty complications and the overall reoperation rate of hypospadias repair."
[Yes] The general interpretation of the results and implications for future research are provided.

P27. Funding: "The authors declare that the research was conducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could be construed as a potential conflict of interest."
[Yes] The sources of funding for the systematic review are described.

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Ideal timing of orchiopexy: a systematic review" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The aim of this study was to determine, based on a systematic review, the most favorable age at which orchiopexy should be performed." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The ideal timing of orchiopexy for cryptorchidism has long been debated." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To assess the ideal timing for orchiopexy with respect to both fertility and malignancy outcomes." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "We included all studies that examined the effect of age at orchiopexy on fertility or malignancy." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "We conducted electronic searches of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE, Embase, and CINAHL to find relevant articles." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: Not reported [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Two researchers independently performed each level of screening, comparing the selected studies to reach a consensus." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: "One researcher extracted data from each of the included studies, and a second researcher checked the data for accuracy and completeness." [Yes]
P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: "We used the MINORS criteria to assess the quality of all relevant non-randomized studies." [Yes]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported [NA]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no additional analyses) [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "Our initial search yielded 198 studies. After screening, we quality assessed the 32 remaining studies that met our criteria." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Publication dates ranged from 1974 to 2011." [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: "We found one RCT that included fertility potential as an outcome which received a Jadad score of 3." [Yes]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Fertility potential was greatest when orchiopexy was performed before 1 year of age." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no additional analyses) [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Orchiopexy between 6 and 12 months of age may optimize fertility potential and help protect against the increased risk of testicular cancer associated with cryptorchidism." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The most direct measurement of male fertility is paternity rate and time until conception of a live born child, but these outcomes are difficult to assess." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Our study is the first step towards determining the ideal management of undescended testes." [Yes]
P27. Funding: "This research was carried out as part of the development of the Canadian Association of Pediatric Surgeons (CAPS) Evidence-Based Resource." [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The aim of this study was to determine, based on a systematic review, the most favorable age at which orchiopexy should be performed." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The ideal timing of orchiopexy for cryptorchidism has long been debated." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To assess the ideal timing for orchiopexy with respect to both fertility and malignancy outcomes." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "We included all studies that examined the effect of age at orchiopexy on fertility or malignancy." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "We conducted electronic searches of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE, Embase, and CINAHL to find relevant articles." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: Not reported [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Two researchers independently performed each level of screening, comparing the selected studies to reach a consensus." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: "One researcher extracted data from each of the included studies, and a second researcher checked the data for accuracy and completeness." [Yes]
P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: "We used the MINORS criteria to assess the quality of all relevant non-randomized studies." [Yes]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported [NA]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no additional analyses) [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "Our initial search yielded 198 studies. After screening, we quality assessed the 32 remaining studies that met our criteria." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Publication dates ranged from 1974 to 2011." [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: "We found one RCT that included fertility potential as an outcome which received a Jadad score of 3." [Yes]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Fertility potential was greatest when orchiopexy was performed before 1 year of age." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no additional analyses) [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Orchiopexy between 6 and 12 months of age may optimize fertility potential and help protect against the increased risk of testicular cancer associated with cryptorchidism." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The most direct measurement of male fertility is paternity rate and time until conception of a live born child, but these outcomes are difficult to assess." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Our study is the first step towards determining the ideal management of undescended testes." [Yes]
P27. Funding: "This research was carried out as part of the development of the Canadian Association of Pediatric Surgeons (CAPS) Evidence-Based Resource." [Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Comparing the efficacy and safety between robotic-assisted versus open pyeloplasty in children: a systemic review and meta-analysis" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "This manuscript is mainly to systemically review the published reports that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic-assisted (RP) versus open pyeloplasty (OP) in children with ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJO)." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Open dismembered pyeloplasty remained the best standard treating children with ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJO) despite the introduction of minimal invasive therapy." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "This manuscript is mainly to systemically review the published reports that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic-assisted (RP) versus open pyeloplasty (OP) in children with ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJO)." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "We searched PubMed® for comparative studies (from January 1990 to 2014 September) that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic versus open pyeloplasty." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "We searched PubMed® for comparative studies (from January 1990 to 2014 September) that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic versus open pyeloplasty." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: "We used the following keywords: robotic, pyeloplasty, ureteropelvic junction obstruction, children, and pediatric." [Yes]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Two authors (Hsu and Chang) of the current study independently searched and reviewed the articles." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Two authors of this paper, Hsu and Chang, evaluated the quality of the study." [Yes]
P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported [No]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "Initial research yielded 104 abstracts, and a total of 102 abstracts were included for evaluation after duplicates were removed." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Totally, seven retrospective comparative trials [9–15] and three studies [4, 16, 17] using national database were included." [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Most studies reported median value of patient age, operative time, and hospital stay." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "The current meta-analysis fails to validate robotic pyeloplasty as a standard of care in managing pediatric UPJO in the current status." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The included studies were all retrospective in origin with lack of prospective data." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "We urge the pediatric laparoendoscopists and manufacturer to improve the surgical efficacy and safety of pediatric robotic-assisted pyeloplasty." [Yes]
P27. Funding: "The study is partly funded by Taipei Tzu Chi Hospital, Buddhist Tzu Chi Medical Foundation." [Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
[No] The title does not clearly identify the report as a systematic review or meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
[No] The abstract does not provide a structured summary with all the required information.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
[Yes] The introduction describes the rationale for the review.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
[Yes] The introduction provides an explicit statement of the objectives with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
[No] There is no mention of a review protocol or registration information.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
[Yes] The methods specify the eligibility criteria used for study and report characteristics.

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
[No] There is no description of the information sources used in the search.

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
[No] The full electronic search strategy is not presented.

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
[Yes] The methods state the process for selecting studies.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
[Yes] The methods describe the method of data extraction from reports.

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
[Yes] The methods list and define the variables for which data were sought.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
[Yes] The methods describe the methods used for assessing risk of bias in individual studies.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
[No] The principal summary measures are not stated.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
[No] There is no flow diagram or detailed information on the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
[Yes] The results present characteristics for each study and provide the citations.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
[Yes] The results present data on risk of bias within studies.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
[Yes] The results present simple summary data for each intervention group.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
[Yes] The discussion summarizes the main findings and their relevance.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
[Yes] The discussion discusses the limitations of the study.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
[Yes] The discussion provides a general interpretation of the results and implications for future research.

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
[No] There is no description of the sources of funding for the systematic review.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
[Yes] The results present simple summary data for each intervention group.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
[Yes] The discussion summarizes the main findings and their relevance.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
[Yes] The discussion discusses the limitations of the study.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
[Yes] The discussion provides a general interpretation of the results and implications for future research.

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
[No] There is no description of the sources of funding for the systematic review.

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Is Screening of Intestinal Foregut Anatomy in Heterotaxy Patients Really Necessary? A Systematic Review in Search of the Evidence"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "Objective: (1) Is screening of intestinal rotational anatomy obligatory in “asymptomatic” patients with heterotaxy? (2) Does detection of an anomaly warrant surgical correction?"
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Heterotaxy is an abnormal arrangement of thoraco-abdominal viscera across a left-to-right axis. Intestinal rotational anomalies are frequent among patients with heterotaxy, but debate exists as to whether they are benign in nature, requiring careful observation alone, or if surgical correction is warranted to prevent obstruction or midgut volvulus."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "we undertook a systematic review of the available literature to determine (1) whether screening of IRA is obligatory in “asymptomatic” patients with heterotaxy and (2) whether detection of a rotational anomaly warrant(s) surgical correction in such a fragile patient cohort."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No mention of a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Eligibility criteria were then applied to remaining studies"
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A systematic search of the English language literature was conducted using a keyword algorithm (Supplemental Figure 1, https://links.lww.com/SLA/A928). The search was conducted using the indexed databases: CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases, from inception to January 11, 2015 (the search was again updated on June 18, 2015). Additional articles were identified through the reference listings of those articles yielded through the initial electronic database search. The conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade were also searched. Finally, data regarding patients with heterotaxy from our own institution were also obtained."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: "The search was conducted using the indexed databases: CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases, from inception to January 11, 2015 (the search was again updated on June 18, 2015). Additional articles were identified through the reference listings of those articles yielded through the initial electronic database search. The conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade were also searched."
[Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Eligibility criteria were then applied to remaining studies"
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: No specific mention of data extraction process.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items: No specific mention of variables sought or assumptions made.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No mention of risk of bias assessment.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: No mention of principal summary measures.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no additional analyses conducted).
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "Nineteen studies met the eligibility criteria but reporting was adequate for 9."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "All studies were retrospective case series"
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No specific mention of risk of bias assessment.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Of 414 patients managed expectantly, only a single patient (0.24%) developed symptoms directly attributable to IRA during the total follow-up period."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no additional analyses conducted).
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "This systematic review shows that “asymptomatic patients” with heterotaxy are at a low risk of developing IRA-related complications."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "We fully acknowledge that there are some limitations with the present study."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "This systematic review has robustly demonstrated that the evidence base for foregut imaging screening in “asymptomatic patients” with heterotaxy is substantially weak."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: No mention of funding sources.
[No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Meta-analysis of robot-assisted vs conventional laparoscopic and open pyeloplasty in children" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "To critically analyse outcomes for robot-assisted pyeloplasty (RAP) vs conventional laparoscopic pyeloplasty (LP) or open pyeloplasty (OP) by systematic review and meta-analysis of published data." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "It remains largely unclear how the many technological enhancements offered by robot-assistance might translate into clinically measurable outcome benefits." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The aim of the present study was therefore to undertake a meta-analysis of RAP vs LP and OP in children." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No information provided [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Only comparative studies investigating RAP vs LP or OP in children were included." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "Studies published up to December 2013 were identified from multiple literature databases." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: No information provided [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Two authors independently undertook literature searches, screened abstracts, and assessed eligible articles against inclusion criteria." [Yes]
P11. Methods / Data items: No information provided [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No information provided [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Effect sizes were estimated by pooled odds ratios and weighted mean differences." [Yes]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: No meta-analysis performed [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: No information provided [No]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: No additional analyses performed [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "In all, 12 studies met the inclusion criteria, involving 384 RAP, 131 LP, and 164 OP procedures." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Characteristics of studies included in the meta-analysis" [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No information provided [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Pooled analyses determined no significant differences between RAP and LP or OP for all primary outcomes." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: No meta-analysis performed [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: No information provided [No]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: No additional analyses performed [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Existing evidence shows largely comparable outcomes amongst surgical techniques available to treat pelvi-ureteric junction obstruction in children." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias)." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research." [Yes]
P27. Funding: "Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review." [Yes]
